channel.title: Vestibule :: Suggestions for "Opal, get back at doing Ruby on your browser ☺"
channel.description: A list of all suggestions made for "Opal, get back at doing Ruby on your browser ☺"

item.title: Suggestion from Paul Battley (@threedaymonk)
item.description:
As someone who implemented a simple Ruby-to-JavaScript proof-of-concept transpiler many years ago, I'm very interested in this talk, and especially in the details of how you implemented the Ruby object model.

I still don't think the title's quite right: get back at* means "exact revenge upon". You probably want get back to, in the sense of "return to", yes?

item.title: Suggestion from Josep M. Bach (@txus)
item.description: This sounds really interesting! The details on the internals I'd find particularly interesting to learn, as well as issues discovered while implementing it (cross-browser issues maybe?).

item.title: Suggestion from the proposer
item.description: Thanks for the correction John, I'll layout the main points and update the description.

item.title: Suggestion from John Pagonis (@)
item.description:
The talk seems very interesting, as I said. however to be fair to others and in order for everyone to know what they are voting for, I'd like to see more details about the talk. Perhaps a bulleted skeleton would help?

btw the title needs a minor correction "Opal, get back at doing Ruby...." :-)

item.title: Suggestion from Nikos Dimitrakopoulos (@)
item.description: Super! I would suggest to update the proposal description to reflect this :)

item.title: Suggestion from the proposer
item.description: Some internals will be there along with an overview, thanks for the feedback!

item.title: Suggestion from Nikos Dimitrakopoulos (@)
item.description: Totally agree with what John said. Even though it sounds interesting to see what you can achieve with Opal, some information regarding how it's implemented would be really nice!

item.title: Suggestion from John Pagonis (@)
item.description:
Is this only about usage of Opal or does it also cover its internals as well?

I'd suggest that you cover both intro/usage of Opal as well as its design. I also hope it is not just an intro tutorial with basic info which anyone could pick from the Opal site.

I for once i'm interested in the subject btw :-)
